Text: Russia is a bad actor, but Vladimir Putin is someone we should not talk to, because the only way he will stop is to sense strength and resolve on the other side, and we have all of that within our control.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We could rebuild the Sixth Fleet. I will. We haven't. We could rebuild the missile defense program. We haven't. I will. We could also, to Senator Rubio's point, give the Egyptians what they've asked for, which is intelligence.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We could give the Jordanians what they've asked for...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...bombs and material. We have not supplied it...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...I will. We could arm the Kurds. They've been asking us for three years. All of this is within our control.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you. Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: While you're - while you brought up the subject of General Suleimani of the Quds forces from Iran, the next president, no matter who he or she may be, will inherit President Obama's Iran deal.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Cruz, Governor Kasich says that anyone who is promising to rip up the Iran deal on day one, as you have promised to do, is, quote, "inexperienced," and, quote, "playing to a crowd." Respond to Governor Kasich, please.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Well, let me tell you, Jake, the single biggest national security threat facing America right now is the threat of a nuclear Iran. We've seen six and a half years of President Obama leading from behind. Weakness is provocative, and this Iranian nuclear deal is nothing short of catastrophic.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: This deal, on its face, will send over $100 billion to the Ayatollah Khamenei, making the Obama administration the world's leading financier of radical Islamic terrorism.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: This deal abandons four American hostages in Iran, and this deal will only accelerate Iran's acquiring nuclear weapons. You'd better believe it. If I am elected president, on the very first day in office, I will rip to shreds this catastrophic Iranian nuclear deal.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Why is that not, as Governor Kasich says, playing to the crowd and an example of you being inexperienced?

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Well, let's be clear when it comes to experience. What President Obama wants to do is he's run to the United Nations, and he wants to use the United Nations to bind the United States, and take away our sovereignty. Well, I spent five and a half years as a Solicitor General of Texas, the lead lawyer for the state, in front of the U.S. Supreme Court, and I went in front of the Supreme Court, and took on the world court of the United Nations in a case called Medellin v. Texas, and we won a historic victory saying the World Court, and the U.N., has no power to bind the United States, and no President of the United States, Republican or Democrat, has the authority to give away our sovereignty.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: And, so, if there's anyone up here who would be bound by this catastrophic deal with Iran, they're giving up the core responsibility of commander in chief, and as president, I would never do that.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Kasich...

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ...Yeah, well...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Did Senator Cruz just play to the crowd?

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Well, let me just say this. First of all, I think it's a bad agreement, I would never have done it. But, you know, a lot of our problems in the world today is that we don't have the relationship with our allies. If we want to go everywhere alone, we will not have the strength as (ph) if we could rebuild with our allies.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Now, this agreement, we don't know what's going to happen in 18 months. I served on the Defense Committee for 18 years. I've seen lots of issues in foreign affairs, and foreign - in terms of global politics, you have to be steady.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Now, here's the - if they cheat, we slap the sanctions back on. If they help Hamas, and Hezbollah, we slap the sanctions back on. And, if we find out that they may be developing a nuclear weapon, than the military option is on the table. We are stronger when we work with the Western civilization, our friends in Europe, and just doing it on our own I don't think is the right policy.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Thank you, Governor. I want to go to Senator Paul.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ...Slow (ph) and steady, (inaudible) chicken...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to go to Senator Paul. Senator Paul, the White House is rolling out the red carpet next week for the President of China, President Xi. Governor Walker says that President Obama should cancel the state dinner because of China's currency manipulation, and because of China's alleged cyber attacks against the United States.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Is Governor Walker right?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: I think this goes back to essentially what we've been saying for the last two or three questions. Carly Fiorina also said we're not going to talk with Putin. Well, think if Reagan had said that during the Cold War? We continued to talk with the Russians throughout the Cold War which is much more significant that where we are now.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Should we continue to talk with Iran? Yes. Should we cut up the agreement immediately? That's absurd. Wouldn't you want to know if they complied? Now, I'm going to vote against the agreement because I don't think there's significant leverage, but it doesn't mean that I would immediately not look at the agreement, and cut it up without looking to see if whether or not Iran has complied.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: The same goes with China. I don't think we need to be rash, I don't think we need to be reckless, and I think need to leave lines of communication open. Often we talk about whether we should be engaged in the world, or disengaged in the world, and I think this is an example of some who want to isolate us, actually, and not be engaged.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: We do need to be engaged with Russia. It doesn't mean we give them a free pass, or China a free pass, but, to be engaged, to continue to talk. We did throughout the Cold War, and it would be a big mistake not to do it here.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Walker, Senator Paul seemed to suggest...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...that canceling the state dinner would be rash, and reckless.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: Two parts to that, one on China, one back for a second on Iran.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: When it comes to China, why would we be giving an official state visit to a country that's been involved in a massive cyber attack against the United States? That's not just a visit, that's a 21 gun salute on the South Lawn of the White House. It just doesn't make any sense. If we're ever going to send a message to them, wouldn't this be the time, when they've issued this, sort of, massive attack against us?

Speaker: WALKER
Text: And, Jake, for the question, I was one of the first ones to call for terminating the bad deal with Iran on day one. The President came after me and said I need to bone up. You know, the President who called ISIS the JV squad said I needed to bone up.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: The reality is it's a bad deal on day one, and it's a bad deal because this president has allowed Iran to go closer, and closer.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: I'd love to play cards with this guy because Barack Obama folds on everything with Iran. We need a leader who's going to stand up, and actually (INAUDIBLE)...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...Jake...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Governor Bush...

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ...Jake...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Bush, your father was the chief diplomatic envoy to China back when Nixon opened relations to China. Is Scott Walker's approach the right one, canceling the state dinner?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: No, I don't think so, but we need to be strong against China. We should use offensive tactics as it relates to cyber security, send a deterrent signal to China. There should be super sanctions in what President Obama has proposed. There's many other tools that we have without canceling a dinner. That's not going to change anything, but we can be much stronger as it relates to that.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: As it relates to Iran, it's not a strategy to tear up an agreement. A strategy would be how do we confront Iran? And, the first thing that we need to do is to establish our commitment to Israel which has been altered by this administration. And, make sure that they have the most sophisticated weapons to send a signal to Iran that we have Israel's back.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: If we do that, it's going to create a healthier deterrent effect than anything else I can think of.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to turn...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...Jake, (INAUDIBLE)...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...I want to turn to Governor Huckabee who has been very patient. Somebody had to be 11th, and he is, but, I do want to change the subject to the event that you had...

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: I would certainly love to get in on this, because I think the single...

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ... however you want, but I want to ask this question.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: I've been patiently waiting, and I'm going to just say this about Iran.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: All right, sir, go ahead.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: Because I think it is incredibly important. This is really about the survival of Western civilization. This is not just a little conflict with a Middle Eastern country that we've just now given over $100 billion to, the equivalent in U.S. terms is $5 trillion.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: This threatens Israel immediately, this threatens the entire Middle East, but it threatens the United States of America. And we can't treat a nuclear Iranian government as if it is just some government that would like to have power. This is a government for 36 years has killed Americans, they kidnapped Americans, they have maimed Americans. They have sponsored terrorist groups, Hamas and Hezbollah, and they threaten the very essence of Western civilization.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: To give them this agreement, that the president treats like the Magna Carta, but Iranians treat it like it's toilet paper, and we must, simply, make it very clear that the next president, one of us on this stage, will absolutely not honor that agreement, and will destroy it and will be tough with Iran, because otherwise, we put every person in this world in a very dangerous place.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: OK.

Speaker: (UNKNOWN)
Text: Jake, I'd like to...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We're going to turn now to Hugh Hewitt, from Salem Radio Network.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Jake.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Mr. Trump, two years ago, President Obama drew a red line that the Syrian dictator Bashar Assad crossed, President Obama threatened to strike. He did not, his knees buckled.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: We now have 4 million refugees, Syria is a living hell, and he turned to the Congress for the authority to back him up. You have three senators to your right that said, no. Do they bear responsibility for this refugee crisis, and what would you have done when Bashar Assad crossed the line?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I wouldn't have drawn the line, but once he drew it, he had no choice but to go across. They do bear some responsibility, but I think he probably didn't do it, not for that reason.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Somehow, he just doesn't have courage. There is something missing from our president. Had he crossed the line and really gone in with force, done something to Assad - if he had gone in with tremendous force, you wouldn't have millions of people displaced all over the world.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: How much responsibility, Mr. Trump, do the senators hold?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They had a responsibility, absolutely. I think we have three of them here...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Senator Rubio...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I think they had a responsibility, yes.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Let me tell you - I will tell you we have zero responsibility, because let's remember what the president said. He said the attack he would conduct would be a pinprick. Well, the United States military was not build to conduct pinprick attacks.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: If the United States military is going to be engaged by a commander-in-chief, it should only be engaged in an endeavor to win. And we're not going to authorize use of force if you're not put in a position where they can win.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And quite frankly, people don't trust this president as commander-in-chief because of that.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Senator Paul? PAUL: I think this gets to the point of wisdom on when to intervene and when we shouldn't. Had we bombed Assad at the time, like President Obama wanted, and like Hillary Clinton wanted and many Republicans wanted, I think ISIS would be in Damascus today. I think ISIS would be in charge of Syria had we bombed Assad.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Sometimes both sides of the civil war are evil, and sometimes intervention sometimes makes us less safe. This is real the debate we have to have in the Middle East.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Every time we have toppled a secular dictator, we have gotten chaos, the rise of radical Islam, and we're more at risk. So, I think we need to think before we act, and know most interventions, if not a lot of them in the Middle East, have actually backfired on us.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator Paul.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to turn now to my colleague Dana Bash.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Hold on, a second, Jake, he asked me, as well. I'd like to actually...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: That would be fair, you're right. You're the third senator.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: ... respond. I think I'm the first senator.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: The No. 1 test for use of military force should be the vital national security interest of the United States. The reason why I opposed President Obama bombing Syria, is because he couldn't answer the question what do you do if chemical weapons end up in the hands of radical Islamic terrorists like al-Nusra, like Al Qaida, like ISIS?

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Now, I also want to respond to several folks up here who said we should trust this Iranian deal, see if the Iranians will comply.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Anyone who is paying attention to what Khamenei says knows that they will not comply. There is a reason Khamenei refers to Israel as the little Satan, and America as the great Satan.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: In the middle of negotiating this treaty, Khamenei led the assembled masses in chanting, death to America. I'm reminded of a great editorial cartoon. It shows the Ayatollah Khamenei saying, "Death to all Americans," and then it shows John Kerry coming back, saying, "Can we meet ya half way?"

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: We need a commander-in-chief who will stand up and protect this country. And I'll tell you, I can't wait to stand on that debate stage with Hillary Clinton and to make abundantly clear if you vote for Hillary, you are voting for the Ayatollah Khomeini to possess a nuclear weapon and if you elect me as president, under no circumstances will a theocratic ayatollah who chants death to America ever be allowed to acquire a nuclear weapon.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We're going to go to Dana Bash...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: KASICH
Text: No, no, no. I want to - I want to - I want to say something about what the senator just said.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: And then it'll be my turn.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: No one is - no - let me - let me suggest to you we believe that we operate better in the world when our allies work with us. President Bush did it in the Gulf War. We work better when we are unified.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Secondly, nobody's trusting Iran. They violate the deal, we put on the sanctions, and we have the high moral ground to talk to our allies in Europe to get them to go with us.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: If they don't go with us, we slap the sanctions on anyway. If they fund these radical groups that threaten Israel and all of the West, then we should rip up the deal and put the sanctions back on.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: And let me make it clear - let me make it clear...

Speaker: KASICH
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ... if we think - if we think they're getting close to a - to developing a nuclear weapon and we get that information, you better believe that I would do everything in my power as the commander-in-chief to stop them having a nuclear weapon.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Jake, Jake...

Speaker: KASICH
Text: We can have it, and we can have our allies, and we can be strong as a country, and we can project across this globe with unity, not just doing it alone. That is not what gets us where we want to get as a nation.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Cruz?

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Jake, there is no more important topic in 2016 than this topic right here, and I've listened to several folks saying, "Well, gosh, if they cheat, we'll act."

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: We won't know under this agreement - there are several facilities in Iran they designate as military facilities that are off limit all together. Beyond that, the other facilities, we give them 24 days notice before inspecting them. That is designed to allow them to hide the evidence.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: And most astonishingly, this agreement trusts the Iranians to inspect themselves. That makes no sense whatsoever.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: And let me know - President Obama is violating federal law...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ... by not handing over the side deals, and we ought to see the United States Congress...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ... stand up together and say, "Hand over this treaty, and protect this country."

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator. I want to...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Jake?

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ... turn back to Governor Huckabee...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Jake?

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to turn back to Governor Huckabee.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Huckabee, last week, you held a rally for a county clerk in Kentucky who was jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, as I don't need to tell you.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: You've called what happened to Kim Davis, that clerk, "an example of the criminalization of Christianity." There are several people on the stage who disagree with you.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Bush, for example, says that that clerk is sworn to uphold the law. Is Governor Bush on the wrong side of the criminalization of Christianity?

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: No, I don't think he's on the wrong side of such an issue. Jeb is a friend. I'm not up here to fight with Jeb or to fight with anybody else.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: But I am here to fight for somebody who is a county clerk elected under the Kentucky constitution that 75 percent of the people of that state had voted for that said that marriage was between a man and a woman.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: The Supreme Court in a very, very divided decision decided out of thin air that they were just going to redefine marriage. It's a decision that the other justices in dissent said they didn't have and there wasn't a constitutional shred of capacity for them to do it.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: I thought that everybody here passed ninth-grade civics. The courts cannot legislate. That's what Roberts said. But heck, it's what we learned in civics.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: The courts can't make a law. They can interpret one. They can review one. They can't implement it. They can't force it.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: But here's what happened Because the courts just decided that something was going to be and people relinquished it and the other two branches of government sat by silently - I thought we had three branches of government, they were all equal to each other, we have separation of powers, and we have checks and balances.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: If the court can just make a decision and we just all surrender to it, we have what Jefferson said was judicial tyranny.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: The reason that this is a real issue that we need to think about...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: No, no. Let me finish this one thought, Jake. I haven't gotten that much time, so I'm going to take just what little I can here.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: We made accommodation to the Fort Hood shooter to let him grow a beard. We made accommodations to the detainees at Gitmo - I've been to Gitmo, and I've seen the accommodations that we made to the Muslim detainees who killed Americans.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: You're telling me that you cannot make an accommodation for an elected Democrat county clerk from Rowan County, Kentucky? What else is it other than the criminalization of her faith and the exaltation of the faith of everyone else who might be a Fort Hood shooter or a detainee at Gitmo?

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Well, I'm not telling you that, Governor. But Governor Bush is, because he - because he disagrees. He thinks that Kim Davis swore to uphold the law.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: You disagree? You're not - you don't...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I don't think - you're not stating my views right.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: OK. Please do.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I think there needs to be accommodation for someone acting on faith. Religious conscience is - is - is a first freedom. It's - it's a powerful part of our - of our Bill of Rights.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And, in a big, tolerant country, we should respect the rule of law, allow people in - in - in this country - I'm a - I was opposed to the decision, but we - you can't just say, "well, they - gays can't get married now."

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But this woman, there should be some accommodation for her conscience, just as there should be for people that are florists that don't want to participate in weddings, or bakers. A great country like us should find a way to have accommodations for people so that we can solve the problem in the right way. This should be solved at the local level...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: You did...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so we do agree, Mike.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I was -

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor, you said, quote, "she is sworn to uphold the law."

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: She is, and so if she, based on conscience, can't sign that - that marriage license, then there should be someone in her office to be able to do it, and if the law needs to be changed in the state of Kentucky, which is what she's advocating, it should be changed.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Let me go to my colleague Dana Bash, who has a question.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Governor Kasich, Senator Cruz is so committed to stripping federal funds from Planned Parenthood that it could result in shutting down the federal government in just about two weeks. Do you agree with Senator Cruz's tactic?

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Well, I agree that we should defund Planned Parenthood. I don't know many people in America who don't think that we should, and in my state, we're trying to figure out how to get it done, because we are threatened with the federal government taking all of our Medicaid money away.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: I think there is a way to get this done by giving governors the ability to be able to act to defund Planned Parenthood. But when (ph) it comes to closing down the federal government, you gotta be very careful about that.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: When we shut the government down - if we have a chance at success and it's a great principle, yes. The president of the United States is not going to sign this, and all we're gonna do is shut the government down, and then we're gonna open up - open it up, and the American people are gonna shake their heads and say, "what's the story with these Republicans?"

Speaker: KASICH
Text: So I think there is a way to get to cutting off the funding for Planned Parenthood. I was in the Congress for 18 years, balanced the budget, cut taxes, got it done. Changed welfare, went around the president to get welfare reform done.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: There are ways to do it without having to shut the government down, but I'm sympathetic to the fact that we don't want this organization to get funding, and the money ought to be reprogrammed for family planning in other organizations that don't support this tactic.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: But I would not be for shutting the government down...

Speaker: BASH
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ...because I don't think it's going to work out.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Senator Cruz, I would just add that, on this stage not that long ago, Senator Graham said that this tactic that you're pushing would tank the Republicans' ability to win in 2016.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Well, let me tell you, Dana, number one, I'm proud to stand for life. These Planned Parenthood videos are horrifying. I would encourage every American to watch the videos. See - seeing your Planned Parenthood officials callously, heartlessly bartering and selling the body parts of human beings, and then ask yourself, "are these my values?"

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: These are horrifying. On these videos, Planned Parenthood also essentially confesses to multiple felonies. It is a felony with ten years' jail term to sell the body parts of unborn children for profit. That's what these videos show Planned Parenthood doing.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Absolutely we shouldn't be sending $500 million of taxpayer money to funding an ongoing criminal enterprise, and I'll tell you, the fact that Republican leadership in both houses has begun this discussion by preemptively surrendering to Barack Obama and saying, "we'll give in because Obama threatens a veto."

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: You know, Obama's committed to his principles. His liberal principles, he will fight for them. He says...

Speaker: BASH
Text: Thank you, senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: I will veto any budget that doesn't fund Planned Parenthood, and Republicans surrender. We need to stop surrendering and start standing...

Speaker: BASH
Text: Thank you...

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ...for our principles.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: BASH
Text: Governor - governor, I want to go to you. Is it what Senator Cruz says, a surrender by Republicans?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We're not - what I can tell you is this. We didn't surrender in New Jersey, six years ago, as the brand new first ever pro-life governor of New Jersey since Roe versus Wade, I defended Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And I've vetoed Planned Parenthood funding, now, eight times in New Jersey. Since the day I walked in as governor, Planned Parenthood has not been funded in New Jersey. We stood up and every one of those vetoes has been sustained.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: But here's the problem, we're - we're fighting with each other up here. We agree. Let's ask Hillary Clinton. She believes in the systematic murder of children in the womb to preserve their body parts...

Speaker: BASH
Text: But...

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: ...Dana, in a way that maximizes their value for sale for profit. It is disgusting, and the American people need to hear it...

Speaker: BASH
Text: But is it...

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: ...we shouldn't be fighting with each other. She's the real opponent, she's the real problem.

Speaker: BASH
Text: But, governor, the - but, governor, the reality is, in just two weeks' time...

Speaker: BASH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: BASH
Text: ...we are going to be facing a question about whether or not it's enough to shut down the government to make that statement, because there is still a Democrat in the White House. Do you oppose it or support it?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I'll tell you what - I'll tell you what I'd be willing to fight for. I'll tell you what I'd be willing to fight for. Why will (ph) we put tax reform on the president's desk, so we can simplify this tax system?

Speaker: BASH
Text: Yes or no, do you support this shutdown?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: No, no, it's really important, Dana. We got to talk about what we would be willing to shut down for. Why don't we put tax reform on this president's desk, and make him veto it if that's what he wants to do? Why haven't we repealed and replaced Obamacare?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Make him veto if that's what he wants to do.

Speaker: BASH
Text: We're talking about Planned Parenthood right now.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And why don't we do the same thing with Planned Parenthood?

Speaker: BASH
Text: Can you answer yes or no?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We elected a Republican Congress to do this. And they should be doing it, and they're not. And they're giving the president a pass.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Dana, I'd like to...

Speaker: BASH
Text: One more time. I'm sorry, I just want to get the answer.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I put it in the list, Dana. We should be doing these things and forcing the president to take action.

Speaker: BASH
Text: So you would support a shutdown.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Let's force him to do what he says he's going to do. Now I don't know whether he'll do it or not, but let's force him to do it.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Dana, I would like to link these two issues, both of which are incredibly important, Iran and Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: One has something to do with the defense of the security of this nation. The other has something to do with the defense of the character of this nation. You have not heard a plan about Iran from any politician up here, here is my plan. On day one in the Oval Office, I will make two phone calls, the first to my good friend to Bibi Netanyahu to reassure him we will stand with the state of Israel.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: The second, to the supreme leader, to tell him that unless and until he opens every military and every nuclear facility to real anytime, anywhere inspections by our people, not his, we, the United States of America, will make it as difficult as possible and move money around the global financial system.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We can do that, we don't need anyone's cooperation to do it. And every ally and every adversary we have in this world will know that the United States in America is back in the leadership business, which is how we must stand with our allies.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: As regards Planned Parenthood, anyone who has watched this videotape, I dare Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama to watch these tapes. Watch a fully formed fetus on the table, it's heart beating, it's legs kicking while someone says we have to keep it alive to harvest its brain.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: This is about the character of our nation, and if we will not stand up in and force President Obama to veto this bill, shame on us.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dana, I want to continue on the subject.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Bush, you recently said while discussing Planned Parenthood, quote, you're "not sure we need a half billion for women's health issues." Now you've since said that you misspoke, you didn't mean to say "women's health issues."

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: But Donald Trump said that quote, that comment, which Hillary Clinton did seize upon immediately, will haunt you the same way Mitt Romney's 47 percent video haunted him.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Tell Donald Trump why he's wrong.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, he's wrong on a lot of things, but on this he's wrong because I'm the most pro-life governor on this stage. I got to act on my core beliefs. It's part of who I am. Life is a gift from God. And from beginning end we need to respect it and err on the side of life.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so I defunded Planned Parenthood. We created a climate where parental notification took place. We were the only state to fund crisis pregnancy centers with state moneys. We were totally focused on this. And I would bring that kind of philosophy to Washington, D.C.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: So here is a solution to this. Title X of the HHS funding, there is something that was the "Reagan Rule." It was passed in 1988. And in that rule it was defined, and the courts approved this, that a Planned Parenthood, you couldn't separate the money between the actual abortion procedures, and there are 330,000 abortions that take place in this clinic, and their promotion of it.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: He interpreted it the right way, the courts ruled in his favor, and Planned Parenthood did not get funding during that time until President Clinton came in.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: When I'm elected president, we will restore that interpretation of Title X. And this deal will be finished.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor Bush.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Donald Trump, let me just...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Jeb, just...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: The quote was, "I'm not sure we need half a billion dollars for women's health issues." He said he misspoke. You said that that's going to haunt him. Why do you think that?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I think it will haunt him. I think it's a terrible. I think it's going to haunt him absolutely. He came back later and he said he misspoke. There was no question because I heard when he said the statement. I was watching and he said the statement.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And I said, wow, I can't believe it. I will take care of women. I respect women. I will take care of women.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: One thing we will say and I would like to get back to the Iran situation. We're talking about Iran. The agreement was terrible. It was incompetent. I've never seen anything like it. One of the worst contracts of any kind I've ever seen.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And nobody ever mentions North Korea where you have this maniac sitting there and he actually has nuclear weapons and somebody better start thinking about North Korea and perhaps a couple of other places. But certainly North Korea.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And Ted and I have spoken. We've - a lot of us have spoken. We're talking about Iran. They are bad actors, bad things are going to happen. But in the meantime, you have somebody right now in North Korea who has got nuclear weapons and who is saying almost every other week, I'm ready to use them. And we don't even mention it.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Bush?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: There are 13,000 community-based organizations that provide health services to women, 13,000 in this country. I don't believe that Planned Parenthood should get a penny from the federal government. Those organizations should get funding, just as I increased funding when I was governor of the state.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: That's the way you do this is you improve the condition for people. And, Donald, when I was governor, we also increased the opportunities for women.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Women's income grew three times faster than the national average when I was governor.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: So why didn't you say it? Why didn't you say it?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: We improved - we improved -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I know, but why did you say it? I heard it myself. Why did you say it?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: - we increased child support - we increased child support with a broken system by 90 percent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You said you're going to cut funding for women's health. You said it.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I have a proven record. I have a proven record.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You said it.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to - we're going to get to -

Speaker: WALKER
Text: Jake, just one more moment. This is - there's something bigger to this. Now, I - like so many other governors here, I defunded Planned Parenthood four-and-a-half years ago, in a Blue State. But it's bigger than that. We did that in a Blue State, we took the money and put it into women's health, so we did exactly what we're talking about here.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: But I think the bigger issue here is we should be able to do this nationally, and this is precisely why so many Republicans are upset with Washington. They see the House and they see the Senate and they say why can't we pass this. Why can't we defund Planned - put it in a spending bill.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: Forget about the 60-vote rule, there's no reason - and the Constitution doesn't call for 60 votes. Pass it with 51 votes, put it on the desk of the president -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: - and go forward and actually make a point. This is why -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: - people are upset with Washington.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We're going to - we're going to get to many of these issues. This - we're still in the first block, believe it or not. We're going to get to many of these issues, but before we end this block, Ms. Fiorina, I do want to ask you about this.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: In an interview last week in Rolling Stone magazine, Donald Trump said the following about you. Quote, "Look at that face. Would anyone vote for that? Can you imagine that, the face of our next president?" Mr. Trump later said he was talking about your persona, not your appearance. Please feel free to respond what you think about his persona.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: You know, it's interesting to me, Mr. Trump said that he heard Mr. Bush very clearly and what Mr. Bush said. I think women all over this country heard very clearly what Mr. Trump said.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I think she's got a beautiful face, and I think she's a beautiful woman.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: All right. On that note, in less than two minutes - we're going to take a very quick break. In less than two minutes, the most contentious issue on the campaign trail. And the candidates on the stage are split over how to handle it. That's coming up next.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Please give some applause to the candidates.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Welcome to CNN's Republican Presidential Debate. No topic perhaps has been more combustible in this campaign than the issue of immigration.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump, you have called for deporting every undocumented immigrant, Governor Christie has said, quote, "There are not enough law enforcement officers - local, county, state and federal combined - to forcibly deport 11 to 12 million people."

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Tell Governor Christie how much your plan will cost, and how you will get it done.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Correct. First of all, I want to build a wall, a wall that works. So important, and it's a big part of it.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Second of all, we have a lot of really bad dudes in this country from outside, and I think Chris knows that, maybe as well as anybody.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They go, if I get elected, first day they're gone. Gangs all over the place. Chicago, Baltimore, no matter where you look.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have a country based on laws. I will make sure that those laws are adhered to. These are illegal immigrants. I don't think you'd even be asking this question if I didn't run because when I ran, and I brought this up, my opening remarks at Trump Tower, I took heat like nobody has taken heat in a long time. And, then they found out with the killing of Katie, from San Francisco, and so many other crimes, they found out that I was right.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And, most people, many people, apologized to me. I don't think you'd even be talking about illegal immigration if it weren't for me. So, we have a country of laws, they're going to go out, and they'll come back if they deserve to come back. If they've had a bad record, if they've been arrested, if they've been in jail, they're never coming back. We're going to have a country again. Right now, we don't have a country, we don't have a border, and we're going to do something about it, and it can be done with proper management, and it can be done with heart.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Christie, you and I have talked about this in an interview. You say that his big wall, his plan to deport 11 to 12 million undocumented immigrants, it sounds great, but it's never going to happen.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Tell him why you're skeptical of his plans?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: First of, Jake, I don't yield to anybody on how to enforce the law. I'm the only person on this stage who spent seven years as a United States Attorney after September 11th, and I know how to do this.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: The fact is though that for 15,000 people a day to be deported every day for two years is an undertaking that almost none of us could accomplish given the current levels of funding, and the current number of law enforcement officers. Here's what we need to do, and I think this is where Donald is absolutely right. What we need to do is to secure our border, and we need to do it with more than just a wall.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We need to use electronics, we need to use drones, we need to use FBI, DEA, and ATF, and yes, we need to take the fingerprint of every person who comes into this country on a visa, and when they overstay their visa, we need to tap them on the shoulder, and say, "You have overstayed your welcome, you're taking advantage of the American people. It's time for you to go."

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: If we had that kind of system in place, we wouldn't have the 11 million people we have now.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor Christie...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ...By the way, I agree with - with what Chris is saying, but, I will say this. Illegal immigration is costing us more than $200 billion dollars a year just to maintain what we have.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to bring in Dr. Carson because he too has been skeptical of your plan to immediately deport 11 to 12 million illegal immigrants. He said, quote, "People who say that have no idea what this entails."

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Why do you say that, Dr. Carson?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, first of all, I recognize that we have an incredible illegal immigration problem. I was down in Arizona a few weeks ago at the border. I mean, the fences that were there were not manned, and those are the kind of fences when I was a kid that would barely slow us down. So, I don't see any purpose in having that.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Now, what we need to do is look at something that actually works. Yuma County, Arizona. They stop 97 percent of the illegal immigrants through there. They put in a double fence with a road so that there was quick access by the enforcement people.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: If we don't seal the border, the rest of this stuff clearly doesn't matter. It's kind of ridiculous all the other things we talk about. We have the ability to do it, we don't have the will to do it.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: There was one area where they had cut a hole in the fence, and to repair it, they put a few strands of barb wire across. Well, the photographers who were there with us, they wanted to photograph us from the side of the Mexicans, and they went through there, and they were not physically fit people, and they took their cameras and things with them, and shot us from the other side.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: That's how easy it is to get across. And, the drugs, I mean, it goes on, and on, and on. ICE tells them to release these people, 67,000 criminals released...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Dr. Carson...

Speaker: CARSON
Text: ...on to our property, it's ridiculous.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: With all due respect, you said about Donald Trump's plan to deport 11 to 12 million undocumented immigrants, "People who say that have no idea what this entails."

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Why not?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, I have also said, if anybody knows how to do that, that I would be willing to listen. And, if they can, you know, specify exactly how that's going to be done, and what the cost, and it sounds reasonable, then I think it's worth discussing...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ...(INAUDIBLE)...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...let's continue the conversation about illegal immigration with Dana Bash.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Governor Bush, Mr. Trump has suggested that your views on immigration are influenced by your Mexican born wife. He said that, quote, "If my wife were from Mexico, I think I would have a soft spot for people from Mexico." Did Mr. Trump go to far in invoking your wife?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: He did, he did. You're proud of your family, just as I am.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Correct.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: To subject my wife into the middle of a raucous political conversation was completely inappropriate, and I hope you apologize for that, Donald.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I have to tell you, I hear phenomenal things. I hear your wife is a lovely woman...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: She is. She's fantastic.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I don't know her, and this is a total mischaracterization...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: She is absolutely the love of my life, and she's right here...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Good.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And why don't you apologize to her right now.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: No, I won't do that, because I've said nothing wrong.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But I do hear she's a lovely woman.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: So, here's the deal. My wife is a Mexican-American. She's an American by choice.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: She loves this country as much as anybody in this room, and she wants a secure border. But she wants to embrace the traditional American values that make us special and make us unique.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: We're at a crossroads right now. Are we going to take the Reagan approach, the hopeful optimistic approach, the approach that says that, you come to our country legally, you pursue your dreams with a vengeance, you create opportunities for all of us?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Or the Donald Trump approach? The approach that says that everything is bad, that everything is coming to an end. I...

Speaker: BASH
Text: Mr. Trump?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Jeb said...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I'm on the Reagan side of this.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ... that they come into our country as an act of love.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: With all of the problems we that we have, in so many instances - we have wonderful people coming in. But with all of the problems - this is not an act of love. He's weak on immigration - by the way, in favor of Common Core, which is also a disaster, but weak on immigration.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: He doesn't get my vote.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Mr. Trump...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Dana, with all being said to Mr. Trump...

Speaker: BASH
Text: Go ahead.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Immigration did not come up in 2016 because Mr. Trump brought it up. We talked about it in 2012, we talked about it in 2008. We talked about it in 2004.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Not with this intensity.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We have been talking about it for 25 years. This is why people are tired of politicians.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Ms. Fiorina - Ms. Fiorina, we're going to come to you, we're going to come to you.

Speaker: BASH
Text: I just want to give Governor Bush a chance to respond to what Mr. Trump said.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Look, first of all, I wrote a book about this, three - four years ago, now. And I laid out a comprehensive, conservative approach for immigration reform.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And it does require securing the border. No one disagrees with that. But to build a wall, and to deport people - half a million a month - would cost hundreds of billions of dollars, Donald. Hundreds of billions of dollars. It would destroy community life, it would tear families apart.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And it would send a signal to the rest of the world that the United States values that are so important for our long-term success no longer matter in this country.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: As I said, we are spending $200 billion - we are spending $200 billion a year on maintaining what we have. We will move them out. The great ones will come back, the good ones will come back.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They'll be expedited, they'll be back, they'll come back legally. We'll have a country - they'll come back, legally.

Speaker: BASH
Text: OK, on that note, you have criticized Governor Bush for speaking Spanish on the campaign trail. You said, quote, "He should really set an example by speaking English in the United States."

Speaker: BASH
Text: What's wrong with speaking Spanish?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I think it's wonderful and all, but I did it a little bit half-heartedly, but I do mean it to a large extent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have a country, where, to assimilate, you have to speak English. And I think that where he was, and the way it came out didn't sound right to me. We have to have assimilation - to have a country, we have to have assimilation.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I'm not the first one to say this, Dana. We've had many people over the years, for many, many years, saying the same thing. This is a country where we speak English, not Spanish.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, I've been speaking English here tonight, and I'll keep speaking English.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But the simple fact is, if a high school kid asks me a question in Spanish, a school - by the way, a voucher program that was created under my watch, the largest voucher program in the country, where kids can go to a Christian school, and they ask me a question in Spanish, I'm going to show respect and answer that question in Spanish.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Even though they do speak English, and even though they embrace American values.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: This is a reporter, not a high school kid.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Ms. Dana, I agree that English is the unifying language of our country, and everyone should learn to speak it. It's important.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: I want to tell you a story about someone that didn't speak English that well. It was my grandfather; he came to this country in the 1960s, as a - escaping Cuba. And he lived with us, growing up.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And my grandfather loved America. He understood what was so special about this country. He loved Ronald Reagan; he would be very proud of the fact that we're here this evening.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: My grandfather instilled in me the belief that I was blessed to live in the one society in all of human history where even I, the son of a bartender and a maid, could aspire to have anything, and be anything that I was willing to work hard to achieve.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: But he taught me that in Spanish, because it was the language he was most comfortable in. And he became a conservative, even though he got his news in Spanish.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And so, I do give interviews in Spanish, and here's why - because I believe that free enterprise and limited government is the best way to help people who are trying to achieve upward mobility.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And if they get their news in Spanish, I want them to hear that directly from me. Not from a translator at Univision.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator Rubio.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Cruz - Senator Cruz, this week, we learned more about Dr. Carson's plan for the 11 million to 12 million undocumented immigrants in this country.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson proposed giving these undocumented immigrants a six- month grace period to pay back taxes then to let them become guest workers and only to deport people who failed to do that.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Not exactly what I said.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Well, how would you say it, sir? I was just reading the Wall Street Journal quote, but please tell us.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, what I said, after we seal the borders, after we turn off the spigot that dispenses all the goodies so we don't have people coming in here, including employment, that people who had a pristine record, we should consider allowing them to become guest workers, primarily in the agricultural sphere, because that's the place where Americans don't seem to want to work.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: That's what I said. And they have a six-month period to do that. If they don't do it within that time period, then they become illegal, and as illegals, they will be treated as such.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: OK, from the horse's mouth, Senator Cruz, does that fit your definition of amnesty?

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Well, Jake, you know, I'm - I'm very glad that Donald Trump's being in this race has forced the mainstream media finally to talk about illegal immigration. I think that's very important.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: I like and respect Ben Carson. I'll let him talk about his own plans.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: But I will say this The natural next question that primary voters are asking, after we focus on illegal immigration is, okay, what are the records of the various candidates? And this is an issue on which there are stark differences.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: A majority of the men and women on this stage have previously and publicly embraced amnesty. I am the only candidate on this stage who has never supported amnesty and, in fact, who helped lead the fight to stop a massive amnesty plan.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: In 2013, when Barack Obama and Harry Reid joined the Washington Republicans in a massive, I stood shoulder to shoulder with Jeff Sessions helping lead the fight.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: You know, folks here have talked about, how do you secure the borders? Well, I've been leading the fight in the Senate to triple the Border Patrol, to put in place fencings and walls, to put in place a strong biometric exit/entry system...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Rubio...

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Can I - can I - can I just...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ... I'm not sure...

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Can I correct...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We'll come back to you - we'll come back to you in one second, sir.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: But Senator Rubio, I'm not sure exactly whose plan he's - he's saying is - constitutes amnesty, but I know he has said it about your plan in the past, so I want to give you a chance to respond, then, Dr. Carson, we'll come to you.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: OK.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, let me say that legal immigration is not an issue I read about in the newspaper. Immigration, illegal immigration, all the good aspects of immigration and all the negative ones as well, I live with. My family's immigrants. My neighbors are all immigrants. My in-laws are all immigrants.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: So I've seen every aspect of it, and I can tell you America doesn't have one immigration problem, it has three.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: First, despite the fact that we are the most generous country in the history of the world in allowing people to come here legally, we have people still coming illegally.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Second, we have a legal immigration system that no longer works. It primary is built on the basis of whether you have a relative living here instead of merit.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And third, we have 11 million or 12 million people, many of whom have been here for longer than a decade who are already here illegally.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And we must deal with all three of these problems. We cannot deal with all three of these problems in one massive piece of legislation. I learned that. We tried it that way.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Here's the way forward First, we must - we must secure our border, the physical border, with - with a wall, absolutely. But we also need to have an entry/exit tracking system. 40 percent of the people who come here illegally come legally, and then they overstay the visa. We also need a mandatory e-verify system.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: After we've done that, step two would be to modernize our legal immigration system so you come to America on the basis of what you can contribute economically, not whether or not simply you have a relative living here.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And after we've done those two things, I believe the American people...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: ... will be very reasonable and responsible about what you do with someone who's been here and isn't a criminal. If you're a criminal, obviously, you will not be able to stay.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator - Dr. Carson...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ... I want to give you 30 seconds. I'd like you to answer the question.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Cruz describes plans such as yours as amnesty. Why is your plan not amnesty?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: My plan is not amnesty for a number of reasons.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Number one, you know, I've talked to farmers, and they said they cannot hire Americans to do the kind of job that I'm talking about.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: And the second reason is because the individuals who register as guest workers, they don't get to vote, they are not American citizens, and they don't get the rights and privileges of American citizens. So that's key.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: But the other thing that I want to bring up is, I mentioned something earlier. I think it was just sort of glossed over.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: I talked about the success in Yuma County, I mean, incredible success, and the Department of Justice said, "No, we don't want to do that. That's too successful."

Speaker: CARSON
Text: We don't have to keep reinventing the wheel. All we have to do is look at things that work. All we have to do is use a little common sense.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Dr. Carson. I want to talk about the issue of birthright citizenship, which - which has emerged since the first debate as - as an a - a major issue in this campaign.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump, you say that babies born in the United States to undocumented immigrants should not any longer get automatic American citizenship. Ms. Fiorina says that you are pandering on this issue and acting like the politicians that you rail against. What's your message to Ms. Fiorina on birthright citizenship?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, first of all, the - the 14th Amendment says very, very clearly to a lot of great legal scholars - not television scholars, but legal scholars - that it is wrong. It can be corrected with an act of Congress, probably doesn't even need that.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: A woman gets pregnant. She's nine months, she walks across the border, she has the baby in the United States, and we take care of the baby for 85 years. I don't think so.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And by the way, Mexico and almost every other country anywhere in the world doesn't have that. We're the only ones dumb enough, stupid enough to have it. And people - and by the way, this is not just with respect to Mexico. They are coming from Asia to have babies here, and all of a sudden, we have to take care of the babies for the life of the baby.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: The 14th Amendment, it reads properly, you can go and - it's probably going to be have to be check - go through a process of court, probably ends up at the Supreme Court, but there are a lot of great legal scholars that say that is not correct.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And in my opinion, it makes absolutely no - we're the only - one of the only countries, we're going to take care of those babies for 70, 75, 80, 90 years? I don't think so.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Ms. Fiorina, the vast majority of countries do not have birthright citizenship...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Donald Trump is right about that. Why is it pandering when he's - he says this?

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: First let me say, We have just spent a good bit of time discussing, as Republicans, how to solve this problem. I would ask your audience at home to ask a very basic question. Why have Democrats not solved this problem?

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: President Obama campaigned in 2007 and 2008 on solving the immigration problem. He entered Washington with majorities in the House and the Senate. He could have chosen to do anything to solve this pro - this problem. Instead, he chose to do nothing.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Why? because the Democrats don't want this issue solved.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Ms. Fiorina...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: They want it to be an issue that they can use. As to birthright citizenship...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Please.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...the truth is, you can't just wave your hands and say "the 14th Amendment is gonna go away." It will take an extremely arduous vote in Congress, followed by two-thirds of the states, and if that doesn't work to amend the Constitution, then it is a long, arduous process in court.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: And meanwhile, what will continue to go on is what has gone on for 25 years. With all due respect, Mr. Trump, we've been talking about illegal immigration for 25 years. San Francisco has been a sanctuary city since 1989. There are 300 of them.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: And meanwhile, what has happened? Nothing. The border remains insecure. The legal immigration system remains broken. Look, we know what it takes to secure a border. We've heard a lot of great ideas here. Money, manpower, technology...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...mostly, apparently, leadership...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...the kind of leadership that understands how to get results.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina. Mr. Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I agree 100 percent, by the way, with Carly on the fact that the Democrats do not want to solve this problem, for the obvious reasons, but they do not.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But I believe that a reading of the 14th Amendment allows you to have an interpretation where this is not legal and where it can't be done. I've seen both sides, but some of the greatest scholars agree with me, without having to go through Congress.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If you do go through Congress, you can absolutely solve the problem.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Mr. Trump. Senator Paul...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: But you - you would stipulate, Mr. Trump, but not everyone agrees with you.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: That's true, sure.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: OK.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Paul, I want to bring you in. Where - where do you stand on the issue of birthright citizenship?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Well, I hate to say it, but Donald Trump has a bit of a point here.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: The case that was decided around 1900 was, people had a green card, were here legally, and they said that their children were citizens. There's never been a direct Supreme Court case on people who were here illegally, whether or not their kids are citizens.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: So it hasn't really been completely adjudicated. The 14th Amendment says that "those who are here and under the jurisdiction." The original author of the - of the 14th Amendment said on the Senate floor that this was applying to slaves, and did not specifically apply to others.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: All right. Senator Paul, thank you so much. Let's turn to a new topic. We've received a lot of questions on social media about the economy and about jobs. We have two CEOs on stage right now.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Ms. Fiorina, you were CEO of Hewlett Packard. Donald Trump says you, quote, "ran HP into the ground," you laid off tens of thousands of people, you got viciously fired.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: For voters looking to somebody with private-sector experience to create American jobs, why should they pick you and not Donald Trump?

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: I led Hewlett Packard through a very difficult time, the worst technology recession in 25 years. The NASDAQ stock index fell 80 percent. It took 15 years for the stock index to recover. We had very strong competitors who literally went out of business and lost all of their jobs in the process.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Despite those difficult times, we doubled the size of the company, we quadrupled its topline growth rate, we quadrupled its cash flow, we tripled its rate of innovation.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Yes, we had to make tough choices, and in doing so, we saved 80,000 jobs, went on to grow to 160,000 jobs. And now Hewlett Packard is almost 300,000 jobs. We went from lagging behind to leading in every product category and every market segment.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We must lead in this nation again, and some tough calls are going to be required. But as for the firing, I have been very honest about this from the day it happened. When you challenge the status quo, you make enemies. I made a few. Steve Jobs told me that when he called me the day I was fired to say, hey, been there, done that twice.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: It's also true that the man that led my firing, Tom Perkins, just took -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: - out a full-page ad in the New York Times to say he was wrong, I was right. I was a terrific CEO, the board was dysfunctional. And he thinks I will make a magnificent president of the United States.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina. TRUMP: Well -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump - Mr. Trump, why would you be better at creating jobs than Carly Fiorina?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: - let me - well, let me just explain. The head of the Yale Business School, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, wrote a paper recently, one of the worst tenures for a CEO that he has ever seen, ranked one of the top 20 in the history of business. The company is a disaster and continues to be a disaster. They still haven't recovered. In fact, today, on the front page of the Wall Street Journal, they fired another 25 or 30,000 people saying we still haven't recovered from the catastrophe.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: When Carly says the revenues went up, that's because she bought Compaq, it was a terrible deal, and it really led to the destruction of the company.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Now one other company before that was Lucent. Carly was at Lucent before that. And Lucent turned out to be a catastrophe also. So I only say this. She can't run any of my companies. That I can tell you.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Ms. Fiorina, I want to give you a chance to respond.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: You know, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld is a well-known Clintonite and honestly had it out for me from the moment that I arrived at Hewlett Packard. But honestly, Mr. Trump, I find it quite rich that you would talk about this.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: You know, there are a lot of us Americans who believe that we are going to have trouble someday paying back the interest on our debt because politicians have run up mountains of debt using other people's money. That is in fact precisely the way you ran your casinos. You ran up mountains of debt, as well as losses, using other people's money, and you were forced to file for bankruptcy not once -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I never filed for bankruptcy.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: - not twice, four times, a record four times. Why should we trust you to manage the finances -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I'll tell you why; it's very simple.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: - of this nation any differently than you managed the finances -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I'll tell you. I was running -

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: - of your casinos?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: - Carly, Carly -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: - I've made over $10 billion. I had a casino company - Caesars just filed for bankruptcy. Chris will tell you - it's not Chris' fault either - but almost everybody in Atlantic City is either in trouble or filed for - maybe I'll blame Chris.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Well -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But Atlantic City is a disaster -

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Well, Mr. Trump -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Wait a minute, Carly. Wait. I let you speak. Atlantic City is a disaster, and I did great in Atlantic City. I knew when to get out. My timing was great. And I got a lot of credit for it.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Many of the great business people that you know - and Carl Icon (ph) is going to work with me on making great deals for this country. But whether it's Carl or so many others that we read about all the time -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: - they have used the laws of the land, which is the -

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Christie's name has been invoked. I'd like to give him a 30 second opportunity.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Jake listen. While I'm as entertained as anyone by this personal back-and-forth about the history of Donald and Carly's career, for the 55-year-old construction worker out in that audience tonight who doesn't have a job, who can't fund his child's education, I've got to tell you the truth. They could care less about your careers, they care about theirs.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Let's start talking about that on this stage and stop playing - and stop playing the games. Stop playing -

Speaker: KASICH
Text: There's a -

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: John - I'm not done yet, John.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: A track record of leadership is not a game. It is the issue in this election.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Stop - and stop playing - and Carly - Carly, listen. You can interrupt everybody else on this stage, you're not going to interrupt me, OK?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: The fact is that we don't want to hear about your careers, back and forth and volleying back and forth about who did well and who did poorly. You're both successful people. Congratulations. You know who's not successful? The middle class in this country who's getting plowed over by Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. Let's start talking about those issues tonight and stop this childish back-and-forth between the two of you.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Ms. Fiorina, I want to give you

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Jake -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Kasich, I'm coming to you next, but Ms. Fiorina's name was mentioned, and I have to give her the opportunity to respond if she wants it.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Well, I thought we had been hearing quite a bit about Govenor Christie's record as governor, actually. I think track records are very important. I completely agree that what's at stake here is the future of this nation, and the future of every American.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: But I do think that a track record of leadership is vital because in the end this election is about leadership. And let's talk about what leadership is. It's not about braggadocio, it is about challenging the status quo, solving problems, producing results.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: And the highest calling of leadership is to unlock potential in others.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Problems have festered in Washington for too long. And the potential of this nation is being crushed.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Kasich, I want to come - I'm coming to you. I'm coming to you. Let me ask the question. You can use the time however you want.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: OK, Jake.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Donald Trump says that the hedge fund guys are getting away with murder by paying a lower tax rate. He wants to raise the taxes of hedge fund managers, as does Governor Bush. Do you agree?

Speaker: KASICH
Text: I don't at this point in terms of changing the incentives for investment and risk-taking.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: But let's just stop for a second. There's one person on this stage that does have a record. I'm the only person on the stage and one of the few people in this country that led the effort as the chief architect of the last time we balanced the federal budget.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: We also cut taxes. And when I left Washington in 2000, we had a $5 trillion surplus, and the economy was booming. I had spent 10 years of my life to get us to that point, went out in the private sector, was a great experience, and went into Ohio and took an $8 billion hole and turned it into a $2 billion surplus.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: We've had the largest amount of tax cuts of any sitting governor. We've grown well over 300,000 jobs. You see, I've done it in both places. I'm the only one here that has done it in both places.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: It took a lot to get us to a balanced budget. It was legitimate. It was real. And we negotiated it. A lot of what we're talking about here tonight as we take this position and that position, you know what? At the end of the day, America has got to work.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: We've got to figure out how we come together to deal with this - with our fiscal problems because when we deal with that, we create a stronger economy for everybody. People have a chance to rise.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: So, you know, when we think about how we make a choice, it's the person that lands that plane. It's not somebody that talks about it. It's about the person who has done it. And I've done it in...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ... both places. And I did it including people in the other party. And that's how we were successful.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor Kasich.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: And that's how I will be president, using that experience to drive this country forward. Thank you.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Huckabee, I want to bring you in on the question of hedge fund managers and taxing them. You have said that you are bothered by the fact that hedge fund managers pay such a low tax rate and make 2,500 times what people who work for them make.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Do you agree with what Donald Trump and Governor Bush have proposed, raising their tax rates?

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: I have a different idea. I think we ought to get rid of all the taxes on people who produce. Why should we penalize productivity? And it's why I'm an unabashed supporter of the "fair tax," which would be a tax on our consumption, rather than a tax on our productivity.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: In other words, you're not going to tax anybody for what they earn, whether it's worker whose working by the hour or whether it's a hedge fund manager. If they can produce something and bring capital and labor to create jobs, we need some jobs. And I think the "fair tax" makes more sense.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: Now, Jake, I've been listening to everybody on the stage and there is a lot of back and forth about I'm the only one who has done this, the only one who has done that, I've done great things.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: We've all done great things or we wouldn't be on this stage. But it occurs to me as we're sitting here in the Reagan Library that most of us would like to pay tribute to a guy who, when he got elected, didn't get elected telling everybody how great he was.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: He got elected telling everybody how great the American people were. And he empowered them to live their dreams, which is what I'd love to see us do by no longer penalizing the people who are out there working because they are taking a gut punch right now.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson, you support scrapping the entire tax code and replacing it with a flat tax based on the principal on tithing from the Bible. If you make $10 billion, you pay $1 billion in taxes, if you make $10, you pay $1 in taxes.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Donald Trump believes in progressive taxation. He says it's not right that rich people pay the same as the poor. Tell Donald Trump why his ideas on taxes are wrong.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: It's all about America. You know, the people who say the guy who paid a billion dollars because he had 10, he has still got $9 billion left, that's not fair, we need to take more of his money. That's called socialism. That doesn't work so well.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: What made America into a great nation was the fact that we said, that guy just put in $1 billion, let's create an environment that's even more conducive to his success so that next year he can put in $2 billion.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: And that's the kind of thing that helps us to grow. We can't grow by continuing to take a piece of pie, and dividing it, and redistributing it.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: But, I'm also looking at what doctor - at what Governor Huckabee talked about...

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: ...You don't want me operating on you, I assure you.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: CARSON
Text: The Fair Tax. Looking at both of them, and evaluating them both, and I'm talking to the American people because one of the things we must recognize is that this country is of, for, and by the people. And, it's really time that the government get out of the way, and let the people be the ones who decide how they want to run their country.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ...Well, I'd like to respond, I'd like to respond...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...What do you think of the flat tax? Do you think it's fair?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I think the thing about the flat tax, I know it very well. What I don't like is that if you make $200 million a year, you pay ten percent, you're paying very little relatively to somebody that's making $50,000 a year, and has to hire H&R Block to do the - because it's so complicated.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: One thing I'll say to Ben is that we've had a graduated tax system for many years, so it's not a socialistic thing. What I'd like to do, and I'll be putting in the plan in about two weeks, and I think people are going to like it, it's a major reduction in taxes. It's a major reduction for the middle class. The hedge fund guys won't like me as much as they like me right now. I know them all, but they'll pay more.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I know people that are making a tremendous amount of money and paying virtually no tax, and I think it's unfair.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Mr. Trump. Senator Paul?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Well, I'm glad we're having a discussion about taxes because everybody laments that we lose jobs overseas, we have. Our companies, and our jobs are being chased overseas by a 70,000 page tax code, so, that's why I've chosen to get rid of the whole thing, and have one single rate, 14 and a-half percent for everybody, business, and for corporate income, and personal income. But, we also get rid of the payroll tax, so the working class would get a tax break as well.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: So, I think a flat tax, eliminating the tax code, getting rid of all the loopholes, is the way to go, and it's the way we get America going again.

Speaker: TAPPER
